On Tuesday 30 September 2003 17:07, Jim Dixon wrote:

> The main point is that compilation is a lossy process.  When you write
> i++ it's succinct but very clear.  The compiler translates this into
>   push variable
>   push 1
>   add
>   store variable

Note that there is *no loss of information* in this example.

> While it's not impossible, it's difficult and expensive for a bytecode
> (re)compiler to sort out what's going on here and optimize back to the
> succintness of the original. 

Well ... we must have different notions of both "difficult" and "expensive".
The case above can pretty much be dealt with by peephole optimisation,
a technology so old it's positively decrepit.

recognise "push 1; add" as "addK 1"
recognise "push V; addK 1" as "pushAddK V 1"
recognise "pushAddK V 1; store V" as "inc V"

Flavour to taste.

-- 
Chris "electric hedgehog" Dollin
